elements.content: Five new CuII–AgI, CuII–CuI, and ZnII–AuI complexes have been obtained starting from copper(II) and, respectively, zinc(II) complexes with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands: [{(H2O)(saldmen)Cu}{(NC)Ag(CN)}] 1, 1 ∞[{Cu2(salaepipH)2(μ-CN)}{μ-[Ag(CN)2]}](ClO4)2·4H2O 2, 1 ∞[{(salaepy)Cu}{μ-[Ag(CN)2]}] 3, 1 ∞[{(salaepy)Cu}{μ-[Cu(CN)2]}] 4, [(salaepy)Zn-NCAuCN]2·H2O 5. The Schiff-base ligands (Hsaldmen, Hsalaepip, Hsalaepy) have been obtained by reacting the salicylaldehyde with N,N-dimethyletylenediamine, N-(2-aminoethyl)piperazine, and, respectively, 2-(2-aminoethyl)-pyridine. The structures of compounds 1 and 5 consist of discrete bi- and, respectively, tetranuclear species. The analysis of the packing diagram for crystal 1 reveals the formation of supramolecular double chains sustained by hydrogen-bond interactions involving the aqua ligand. Compounds 2, 3, and 4 are one-dimensional coordination polymers. The structure of 2 consists of chains constructed from {Cu(salaepip)} nodes bridged alternatively by [Ag(CN)2]− and CN– ions, resulted from the partial decomposition of the silver complex. The 3-D architecture of the crystal is constructed from 1-D coordination polymers, [{Cu2(salaepipH)2(μ-CN)}{μ-[Ag(CN)2]}] n 2n+, which are connected by three water molecules that form a triangular water cluster, resulting in a scaffold-like structure with large channels. Compounds 3 and 4 are similar. Their structures can be described as resulting from zigzag anionic chains, [M(CN)2] n n– (M = AgI or CuI), with three-coordinated silver(I) or copper(I) ions, to which monocationic complexes, {(salaepy)Cu}, are attached. The cryomagnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2 have been investigated. Weak antiferromagnetic interactions (J = −2.8 cm–1, H = –JS 1 S 2) mediated by hydrogen bonds are observed for compound 1. The cyanido bridge connecting the basal coordination sites of two copper(II) ions in 2 mediates a moderate antiferromagnetic coupling (J = −55.2 cm–1). Compound 5 exhibits blue luminescence (λ = 464 nm, λex = 400 nm).

elements.content: Copper(II) and zinc(II) complexes with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands are useful tectons in constructing heterometallic complexes with interesting structural features. Five new CuII−AgI, CuII−CuI, and ZnII−AuI complexes have been obtained starting from CuII and ZnII complexes with Schiff bases and using [M(CN)2]− and CN− as ligands. A unique triangular water cluster is described.
elements.clean_text: Copper(II) and zinc(II) complexes with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands are useful tectons in constructing heterometallic complexes with interesting structural features. Five new CuII-AgI, CuII-CuI, and ZnII-AuI complexes have been obtained starting from CuII and ZnII complexes with Schiff bases and using [M(CN)2]- and CN- as ligands. A unique triangular water cluster is described.

elements.content: Schiff bases are among the most popular ligands in coordination chemistry. These molecules are easily obtained in high yields. The number, as well as the relative position of the donor atoms, can be controlled by choosing appropriate carbonyl and primary amine precursors. Many compartmental ligands, which are able to generate homo- and heteropolynuclear complexes, are Schiff bases as well. All these advantages make Schiff-base ligands very good candidates in the effort to synthesize metal complexes of interest in bioinorganic chemistry, catalysis, encapsulation, transport and separation processes, and magnetochemistry. Numerous Schiff-bases with various denticities have been obtained from salicylaldehyde, which result by reacting it with, for example, monoamines, diamines carrying two primary amino groups, and diamines with one primary and one tertiary amino group. In the last case, the condensation reactions lead to tridentate (NNO) Schiff bases. Several examples of (NNO) ligands related to this article are depicted in Scheme . Three structural types have been observed for the complexes resulting from the reaction of a copper(II) salt with a (NNO) ligand in 1:1 molar ratio: (i) mononuclear species, with the copper ion coordinated by the (NNO) ligand, solvent molecules, and, eventually, the anion; (ii) binuclear species with the {Cu(NNO)} moieties bridged by a water molecule; (iii) binuclear species with the copper(II) ions double bridged by the phenoxo oxygen atoms (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Schiff bases are among the most popular ligands in coordination chemistry. These molecules are easily obtained in high yields. The number, as well as the relative position of the donor atoms, can be controlled by choosing appropriate carbonyl and primary amine precursors. Many compartmental ligands, which are able to generate homo- and heteropolynuclear complexes, are Schiff bases as well. All these advantages make Schiff-base ligands very good candidates in the effort to synthesize metal complexes of interest in bioinorganic chemistry, catalysis, encapsulation, transport and separation processes, and magnetochemistry. Numerous Schiff-bases with various denticities have been obtained from salicylaldehyde, which result by reacting it with, for example, monoamines, diamines carrying two primary amino groups, and diamines with one primary and one tertiary amino group. In the last case, the condensation reactions lead to tridentate (NNO) Schiff bases. Several examples of (NNO) ligands related to this article are depicted in Scheme . Three structural types have been observed for the complexes resulting from the reaction of a copper(II) salt with a (NNO) ligand in 1:1 molar ratio: (i) mononuclear species, with the copper ion coordinated by the (NNO) ligand, solvent molecules, and, eventually, the anion; (ii) binuclear species with the {Cu(NNO)} moieties bridged by a water molecule; (iii) binuclear species with the copper(II) ions double bridged by the phenoxo oxygen atoms (Scheme ).

The anionic (NNO) ligands can block three coordination sites at the metal ions, leaving the others available for the interaction with various molecules. In other words, the 1:1 complexes of metal ions with (NNO) ligands can be employed as tectons for constructing polynuclear complexes, when appropriate bridging ligands or metalloligands are used. For example, we have recently shown that interesting cyanido-bridged heterometallic complexes can be obtained by assembling mono- or binuclear copper(II) complex cations with [M(CN)6]3– (M = Cr, Fe, Co) or [Mo(CN)8]3– anions. In this article, we illustrate the potential of the 1:1 complexes of copper(II) and zinc(II) with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands to generate various heterometallic systems with interesting magnetic and luminescence properties.

For example, we have recently shown that interesting cyanido-bridged heterometallic complexes can be obtained by assembling mono- or binuclear copper(II) complex cations with [M(CN)6]3- (M = Cr, Fe, Co) or [Mo(CN)8]3- anions. In this article, we illustrate the potential of the 1:1 complexes of copper(II) and zinc(II) with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands to generate various heterometallic systems with interesting magnetic and luminescence properties.

elements.content: Except where mentioned, all the chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used as received. The starting complexes, [Cu2(saldmen)2(μ-H2O)(H2O)2](ClO4)2·2H2O, [Cu(salaepy)(H2O)]2(ClO4)2, and [Zn(salaepy)(NO3)2]2, were prepared following the literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Except where mentioned, all the chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used as received. The starting complexes, [Cu2(saldmen)2(μ-H2O)(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅2H2O, [Cu(salaepy)(H2O)]2(ClO4)2, and [Zn(salaepy)(NO3)2]2, were prepared following the literature procedures.

elements.content: To an acetonitrile–water (1:1) solution (20 mL) containing 1.5 mmol of [Cu2(saldmen)2(H2O)(H2O)2](ClO4)2·2H2O, 10 mL of acetonitrile–water (1:1) solution containing 1 mmol of K[Ag(CN)2] were added under stirring. Green-blue crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation at room temperature. Yield: 85%. Elemental chemical analysis: 36.08% C, 3.95% H, 12.34% N (calcd); 36.25% C, 3.62% H, 12.48% N (found). Selected IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3444(m), 2930(w), 2171(m), 2139(m), 1634(vs), 1598(vs), 1530(s), 1547(s), 1464(s), 1373(m), 1244(m), 1195(m), 906(w), 767(m), 542(w). Diffuse reflectance spectrum: 409 nm, and a large band between 600 and 800 nm.

elements.content: The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were collected on a Bruker Tensor 37 spectrophotometer in the 4000–400 cm–1 range. UV–vis spectra (diffuse reflectance technique) were recorded on a JASCO V-670 spectrophotometer, using MgO as a standard. Fluorescence measurements were made with a JASCO FP 6500 spectrofluorimeter. Magnetic measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples restrained in eicosane, with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T magnet. Data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the samples using Pascal constants and for the diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder and eicosane by measurement.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

The IR spectra (KBr pellets) were collected on a Bruker Tensor 37 spectrophotometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 range. UV-vis spectra (diffuse reflectance technique) were recorded on a JASCO V-670 spectrophotometer, using MgO as a standard. Fluorescence measurements were made with a JASCO FP 6500 spectrofluorimeter. Magnetic measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples restrained in eicosane, with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T magnet. Data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the samples using Pascal constants and for the diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder and eicosane by measurement.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer operating with a Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) X-ray tube with a graphite monochromator. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques based on F 2. The non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, and hydrogen atoms of the ligands were introduced at calculated positions (riding model), included in structure factor calculations but not refined. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in compounds 1–2 and the hydrogen atoms of the secondary amino group of the piperazine moiety in 2 have been observed and refined with restraints for O–H and N–H bond lengths, respectively. Calculations were performed using SHELX-97 crystallographic software package. A summary of the crystallographic data and the structure refinement for crystals 1–5 is given in Table . CCDC reference numbers: 859345-859349.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer operating with a Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) X-ray tube with a graphite monochromator. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques based on F 2. The non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, and hydrogen atoms of the ligands were introduced at calculated positions (riding model), included in structure factor calculations but not refined. The hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in compounds 1-2 and the hydrogen atoms of the secondary amino group of the piperazine moiety in 2 have been observed and refined with restraints for O-H and N-H bond lengths, respectively. Calculations were performed using SHELX-97 crystallographic software package. A summary of the crystallographic data and the structure refinement for crystals 1-5 is given in Table . CCDC reference numbers: 859345-859349.

The binuclear complexes depicted in Scheme can be employed as precursors for heterometallic systems. The water molecules coordinated to the metal ions are easily replaced by metalloligands. The metalloligands we have chosen for this work are dicyanido silver(I) and gold(I) complexes, [M(CN)2]−. The binuclear core can be preserved or not after the interaction with the metalloligand. In the last case, mononuclear moieties {M(NNO)} are found within the resulted heterometallic complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The binuclear complexes depicted in Scheme  can be employed as precursors for heterometallic systems. The water molecules coordinated to the metal ions are easily replaced by metalloligands. The metalloligands we have chosen for this work are dicyanido silver(I) and gold(I) complexes, [M(CN)2]-. The binuclear core can be preserved or not after the interaction with the metalloligand. In the last case, mononuclear moieties {M(NNO)} are found within the resulted heterometallic complexes.

elements.content: By reacting the aqua-bridged binuclear complex, [Cu2(saldmen)2(μ-H2O)(H2O)2](ClO4)2·2H2O, with K[Ag(CN)2], we obtained a binuclear complex [{(H2O)(saldmen)Cu}{(NC)Ag(CN)}] 1, the dicyanido-argentate anion acting as a monodentate ligand (Figure a). The copper ions are pentacoordinated with a square pyramidal geometry, the apical position being occupied by the aqua ligand (Cu–O2 = 2.321(4) Å). The basal plane is described by two nitrogen atoms and one oxygen arising from the Schiff base, and one nitrogen from the bridging cyanido group. The metal-donor atom distances in the basal plane vary between 1.937(4) and 2.070(5) Å. The intramolecular Cu···Ag distance is 5.17 Å. This heterometallic complex generates a monodimensional supramolecular chain through a quite interesting interplay of hydrogen-bond interactions. First of all, we notice that the aqua ligand does not act in 1 as a bridge between the two copper ions, as in the starting compound. However, a supramolecular {Cu2} entity is formed through hydrogen bonds established between the aqua ligand from one {Cu(saldmen)(H2O)} unit and the phenoxo oxygen atom from the other one (O2···O1′ = 2.826 Å; ′ = −x, 1 – y, 2 – z), Figure a. The aqua ligand is also hydrogen bonded to the nitrogen atom of the terminal cyanido group from a neighboring heterobinuclear complex (O2–N2A″ = 2.911 Å; ″ = x, y, 1 + z), resulting in a supramolecular double chain running along the crystallographic c axis (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Crystal Structures

By reacting the aqua-bridged binuclear complex, [Cu2(saldmen)2(μ-H2O)(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅2H2O, with K[Ag(CN)2], we obtained a binuclear complex [{(H2O)(saldmen)Cu}{(NC)Ag(CN)}] 1, the dicyanido-argentate anion acting as a monodentate ligand (Figure a). The copper ions are pentacoordinated with a square pyramidal geometry, the apical position being occupied by the aqua ligand (Cu-O2 = 2.321(4) Å). The basal plane is described by two nitrogen atoms and one oxygen arising from the Schiff base, and one nitrogen from the bridging cyanido group. The metal-donor atom distances in the basal plane vary between 1.937(4) and 2.070(5) Å. The intramolecular Cu⋅⋅⋅Ag distance is 5.17 Å. This heterometallic complex generates a monodimensional supramolecular chain through a quite interesting interplay of hydrogen-bond interactions. First of all, we notice that the aqua ligand does not act in 1 as a bridge between the two copper ions, as in the starting compound. However, a supramolecular {Cu2} entity is formed through hydrogen bonds established between the aqua ligand from one {Cu(saldmen)(H2O)} unit and the phenoxo oxygen atom from the other one (O2⋅⋅⋅O1' = 2.826 Å; ' = -x, 1 - y, 2 - z), Figure a. The aqua ligand is also hydrogen bonded to the nitrogen atom of the terminal cyanido group from a neighboring heterobinuclear complex (O2-N2A" = 2.911 Å; " = x, y, 1 + z), resulting in a supramolecular double chain running along the crystallographic c axis (Figure b).

elements.content: The reaction between the copper precursor, obtained in situ from Hsalaepip and copper(II) perchlorate, and K[Ag(CN)2] leads to a 1-D coordination polymer constructed from {Cu(salaepip)} nodes bridged alternatively by [Ag(CN)2]− and CN– ions, resulted from the partial decomposition of the silver complex: 1 ∞[{Cu2(salaepipH)2(μ-CN)}{μ-[Ag(CN)2]}](ClO4)2·4H2O 2 (Figure a). The organic ligand is neutral, but the proton from the OH phenoxo group migrated to the secondary amino group of the piperazine moiety (both hydrogen atoms have been observed from the crystallographic data).

The organic ligand is neutral, but the proton from the OH phenoxo group migrated to the secondary amino group of the piperazine moiety (both hydrogen atoms have been observed from the crystallographic data).

elements.content: The copper(II) ions are pentacoordinated with a square pyramidal geometry: the basal plane is formed by one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms from the Schiff base and the cyanido anion that bridges another copper(II) ion; the apical position is occupied by a cyanido group arising from [Ag(CN)2]−, which connects the apical positions of two copper(II) ions. The 1-D coordination polymer can be described as being constructed from binuclear copper(II) nodes, with the copper ions connected by a cyanido group, and [Ag(CN)2]− spacers. The distance between the copper ions within the node is 5.12 Å, while the distance between the copper ions connected by [Ag(CN)2]− is 10.52 Å.
elements.clean_text: The copper(II) ions are pentacoordinated with a square pyramidal geometry: the basal plane is formed by one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms from the Schiff base and the cyanido anion that bridges another copper(II) ion; the apical position is occupied by a cyanido group arising from [Ag(CN)2]-, which connects the apical positions of two copper(II) ions. The 1-D coordination polymer can be described as being constructed from binuclear copper(II) nodes, with the copper ions connected by a cyanido group, and [Ag(CN)2]- spacers. The distance between the copper ions within the node is 5.12 Å, while the distance between the copper ions connected by [Ag(CN)2]- is 10.52 Å.

elements.content: The analysis of the packing diagram reveals interesting features. First of all, we observe that the crystallization water molecules are involved in two structural motifs (Figure b): (i) two water molecules (O2W···O2W′) are hydrogen bonded within the binuclear node, each one being linked to the phenoxo oxygen from one ligand and the uncoordinated piperazine nitrogen from the other ligand (O···O2W = 2.731 Å, N2···O2W′ = 2.791 Å; ′ = 0.3333 – x, 0.66667 – y, 0.66667 – z); (ii) the other water molecules (O1W) construct trimeric clusters. The O1W molecules are disordered over two positions with site occupancy factors of 0.72 (O1W2) and 0.28 (O1W1).
elements.clean_text: The analysis of the packing diagram reveals interesting features. First of all, we observe that the crystallization water molecules are involved in two structural motifs (Figure b): (i) two water molecules (O2W⋅⋅⋅O2W') are hydrogen bonded within the binuclear node, each one being linked to the phenoxo oxygen from one ligand and the uncoordinated piperazine nitrogen from the other ligand (O⋅⋅⋅O2W = 2.731 Å, N2⋅⋅⋅O2W' = 2.791 Å; ' = 0.3333 - x, 0.66667 - y, 0.66667 - z); (ii) the other water molecules (O1W) construct trimeric clusters. The O1W molecules are disordered over two positions with site occupancy factors of 0.72 (O1W2) and 0.28 (O1W1).

elements.content: The observation of water clusters in crystals is of current interest in Chemistry and Biology. Numerous water clusters of various nuclearities, (H2O) n , have been described in the recent years. For the trimeric water clusters, three topologies are possible: linear, angular, with no interactions between the peripheral water molecules, and equilateral triangular. The last one is described for the first time here. The relative stabilities of various topologies of the clusters with a definite number of water molecules have been investigated also from the theoretical point of view. These results of such studies are very useful, but only for gaseous clusters. The size and the topology of the clusters observed in real crystals are definitely influenced by the additional hydrogen bonds established by the crystallization water molecules and their environment (ligands, anions, other solvent molecules). The distances between the water molecules within the trimeric cluster in crystal 2 are 3.075 Å (s.o.f. = 0.72) and 2.786 Å (s.o.f. = 0.28). These clusters are hydrogen bonded to the H2N+ group from the piperazine moiety and probably to the perchlorate ions (Figure c). Since only the hydrogen atoms from the piperazinium moiety have been observed and because of the above-mentioned disorder, it is not possible to identify which are the real hydrogen bonds established between the three water molecules and their neighborhood. The H2N+ group from the piperazine moiety acts as a donor toward the water molecule. The corresponding distances are O1W2···N2 = 2.794 Å (s.o.f. = 0.72) and O1W1···N2 = 2.930 Å (s.o.f. = 0.28). The distances between the water molecules and the oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anions are O1W1···O3P′ = 3.106 Å, O1W1···O3P″ = 3.507 Å, O1W2···O3P″ = 3.800 Å, O1W1···O5P″ = 3.346 Å, and O1W2···O5P″ = 3.074 Å (Figure c, symmetry codes: ′ = 0.3333 – x, 0.66667 – y, 0.66667 – z; ″ = 0.3333 + y, 0.66667 – x + y, 0.66667 – z).

elements.content: The 3-D architecture of the crystal is constructed from the 1-D chains, [{Cu2(salaepipH)2(μ-CN)}{μ-[Ag(CN)2]}] n 2n+, running along the crystallographic c axis, which are connected by the water molecules of the trimeric water clusters, resulting in a scaffold-like structure with large channels (Figure a). Alternatively, the crystal structure can be described as follows: the binuclear units, {Cu2(salaepipH)2(μ-CN)}3+, are connected by the water molecules, resulting in supramolecular layers expanded into the crystallographic ab plane (Figure b). These layers are further connected by the [NCAgCN]− rods. Three such surpamolecular 3-D networks interpenetrate (Figure ).

Alternatively, the crystal structure can be described as follows: the binuclear units, {Cu2(salaepipH)2(μ-CN)}3+, are connected by the water molecules, resulting in supramolecular layers expanded into the crystallographic ab plane (Figure b). These layers are further connected by the [NCAgCN]- rods. Three such surpamolecular 3-D networks interpenetrate (Figure ).

elements.content: A quite interesting heterometallic chain is obtained by reacting [Cu(salaepy)(H2O)](ClO4) with K[Ag(CN)2]: 1 ∞[{(salaepy)Cu}{μ-[Ag(CN)2]}] 3. Its structure can be described as resulting from zigzag anionic chains, [Ag(CN)2] n n–, with three-coordinated silver ions, to which monocationic complexes, {(salaepy)Cu}, are attached (Figure a). The copper ions are tetracoordinated (one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms from the Schiff base and one nitrogen from the cyanido bridge) with a flattened tetrahedral geometry. The copper-donor atom distances vary between 1.885(3) and 2.002(3) Å. The silver atoms are coordinated by three cyanido groups, with a T-shaped geometry. The distances between the metal ions are Ag···Ag = 5.519 Å; Cu···Ag = 5.165 Å. The chains are packed in the crystal in a zipper-like fashion (Figure b). Weak intermolecular C–H···π interactions are established between the chains (C4···Cg = 3.79 Å, where C4 belongs to the pyridyl ring from one chain and Cg is the centroid of the phenyl ring from another chain). A similar complex, 1 ∞[{(salaepy)Cu}{μ-[Cu(CN)2]}] 4, has been obtained reacting the copper precursor with KCN. Part of the copper(II) ions are reduced to copper(I), resulting in a mixed valence CuII/CuI chain (Figure ). The silver ions in 3 are replaced here by copper(I) ions. The copper(I) ions exhibit a stereochemistry closer to the plan-trigonal geometry with the angles between the coordinating atoms of 128.3(2), 124.0(2), and 107.60(19)° (Table ). The aggregation of mixed valence CuII–CuI coordination polymers by reacting a copper(II) complex with KCN or with cyanido complexes releasing easily cyanide ions in solution is observed in several other cases reported in the literature.

The reaction of the binuclear zinc complex [Zn(salaepy)(ONO2)2]2, whose crystal structure was reported by Tandon et al., with K[Au(CN)2] affords a tetranuclerar complex, in which the binuclear {Zn(salaepy)}2 core is preserved and the nitrato ligands are being replaced by [Au(CN)2]− ligands: [(salaepy)Zn-NCAuCN]2·H2O 5 (Figure ). The zinc ions are bridged by the phenoxo oxygen atoms. Each zinc atom is pentacoordinated by two oxygen and two nitrogen atoms arising from the Schiff base and one nitrogen from the bridging cyanido group. The metal–donor atoms distances vary between 1.987(4) and 2.133(4) Å. The coordination geometry of the zinc ions is trigonal bypiramidal, with the apical positions occupied by the phenoxo oxygen and by the azomethine nitrogen atom. The intramolecular Zn···Au distances are 5.09 Å.

The zinc ions are bridged by the phenoxo oxygen atoms. Each zinc atom is pentacoordinated by two oxygen and two nitrogen atoms arising from the Schiff base and one nitrogen from the bridging cyanido group. The metal-donor atoms distances vary between 1.987(4) and 2.133(4) Å. The coordination geometry of the zinc ions is trigonal bypiramidal, with the apical positions occupied by the phenoxo oxygen and by the azomethine nitrogen atom. The intramolecular Zn⋅⋅⋅Au distances are 5.09 Å.

elements.content: It is interesting to observe that in the crystal structure of the binuclear zinc precursor, the nitrato ligands are disposed in trans positions with respect to the {Zn2O2} plane, while in compound 5 the two anionic ligands, [Au(CN)2]−, are disposed in cis positions. This arrangement is most probably favored by the d10–d10 interaction established between the gold atoms (aurophilic interactions). The intramolecular distance between the gold atoms is Au···Au = 3.365 Å. The angle between the two [Au(CN)2]− rods is 26.8°. At the same time, the positions of the pyridyl moieties change from trans in the precursor to cis in compound 5.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to observe that in the crystal structure of the binuclear zinc precursor, the nitrato ligands are disposed in trans positions with respect to the {Zn2O2} plane, while in compound 5 the two anionic ligands, [Au(CN)2]-, are disposed in cis positions. This arrangement is most probably favored by the d10-d10 interaction established between the gold atoms (aurophilic interactions). The intramolecular distance between the gold atoms is Au⋅⋅⋅Au = 3.365 Å. The angle between the two [Au(CN)2]- rods is 26.8°. At the same time, the positions of the pyridyl moieties change from trans in the precursor to cis in compound 5.

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1–5 are collected in Table .

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2 have been investigated in the temperature range 2–300 K. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility, χM, and of the χM T product for the two compounds is presented in Figure . The room temperature value of the χM T product for compound 1 is 0.88 cm3 mol–1K, which corresponds to two noninteracting copper(II) ions. By decreasing the temperature, χM T remains constant down to 90 K, then decreases abruptly, reaching 0.35 cm3 mol–1K at 2 K (Figure a). This behavior indicates a weak intramolecular antiferromagnetic coupling mediated by the hydrogen bonds. Since the interaction of the two copper ions occurs through the hydrogen bond established between the apical aqua ligand from one copper ion and the basal phenoxo oxygen from the other one, the exchange interaction is expected to be weak. The magnetic data have been fitted using the Bleaney–Bowers equation as follows: χ M T = [ 2 N g 2 β 2 / k ] [ 3 + exp ( − J / k T ) ] − 1 where J is the exchange coupling parameter, and N, g, β, and k have their usual meaning. Least-squares fit to the data led to the following values: J = −2.8 cm–1, and g = 2.16.

The magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2 have been investigated in the temperature range 2-300 K. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility, χM, and of the χM T product for the two compounds is presented in Figure . The room temperature value of the χM T product for compound 1 is 0.88 cm3 mol-1K, which corresponds to two noninteracting copper(II) ions. Since the interaction of the two copper ions occurs through the hydrogen bond established between the apical aqua ligand from one copper ion and the basal phenoxo oxygen from the other one, the exchange interaction is expected to be weak. The magnetic data have been fitted using the Bleaney-Bowers equation as follows: 1    χ   M   T =  [ 2 N   g   2     β   2   / k ]     [ 3 + exp  ( - J / k T )  ]    - 1    where J is the exchange coupling parameter, and N, g, β, and k have their usual meaning. elements.content: Compound 2 is more interesting from the magnetic point of view: it gives information about the magnitude of the CuII–CuII exchange interaction mediated by the short cyanido bridge, which connects the copper ions through their equatorial (basal) positions. At room temperature, the value of the χM T product is 0.78 cm3 mol–1K and corresponds to two independent copper(II) ions (Figure b). Upon lowering the temperature, χM T decreases slowly and then more rapidly below 100 K to reach a plateau at ca. 9 K (0.04 cm3 mol–1K). The χM vs T curve shows a maximum at 47 K, clearly indicating an antiferromagnetic interaction between the cyanido-bridged copper(II) ions. The increase of the magnetic susceptibility on cooling below 9K (as well as the low temperature plateau on the χM T vs T curve) is due to a paramagnetic impurity. The magnetic data have been fitted by adding to eq the contribution of the paramagnetic impurity as follows: χ M = ( 1 − ρ ) [ 2 N g 2 β 2 / k ( T − θ ) ] [ 3 + exp ( − J / k T ) ] − 1 + ρ ( N g 2 β 2 / 4 k T ) A Weiss constant, θ, was included to take into account the exchange interactions between the copper dimers as well as other intermolecular interactions, which are expected to be very weak, in comparison with the one occurring along the CuII–CN–CuII pathway. The least-squares fit to the data leads to J = −55.2 cm–1, g = 2.02, θ = −2.3 K, ρ = 0.017. The J value is within the range of values observed with other cyanido-bridged copper(II) dimers. Magneto-structural correlations supported by DFT calculations show that the strength of this exchange interaction is determined by the following factors: (i) the stereochemistry of the copper ion; (ii) the coordination position occupied by the cyanido bridge (apical, equatorial); the value of the Cu–N–C angle; (iii) the relative position of the copper ions with respect to the cyanido bridge (cisoid, transoid). In the case of compound 2, the cyanide ion connects the two copper ions through their basal positions, the magnetic orbital being d x 2–y 2 . The value of the Cu–C/N–N/C angle is 176.7°. Consequently, the exchange interaction in 2 is expected to be weaker than in the case of the binuclear complexes with the cyanido bridge connecting the apical positions of two copper ions exhibiting a trigonal bipyramidal stereochemistry (J values ranging between −100 and −160 cm–1). In this case, the main lobes of the d z 2 magnetic orbitals are pointing toward the bridging cyanide ion. However, the exchange interaction in 2 is expected to be stronger than in complexes with square pyramidal copper ions connected through their apical positions (around −1 cm–1) or in binuclear complexes with trigonal bipyramidal copper(II) ions connected through the equatorial positions (around −10 cm–1).

elements.content: Zinc complexes with Schiff-base ligands are known to exhibit interesting luminescence properties, with emission bands currently located between 390 and 590 nm. The coordination of the ligands to the zinc ion increases the rigidity of the molecular edifice and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless thermal vibrations. The photoluminescent behavior of compound 5 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. It exhibits strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum centered on λem = 464 nm, when the excitation wavelength is 400 nm (Figure a). We have also recorded the luminescence spectrum of the binuclear precursor of [Zn(salaepy)(ONO2)2]2 (Figure b). This compound also shows strong luminescence (λem = 430 nm, λex = 430 nm), which is assignable to intraligand 1(π*−π) fluorescence.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

Zinc complexes with Schiff-base ligands are known to exhibit interesting luminescence properties, with emission bands currently located between 390 and 590 nm. The coordination of the ligands to the zinc ion increases the rigidity of the molecular edifice and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless thermal vibrations. The photoluminescent behavior of compound 5 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. It exhibits strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum centered on λem = 464 nm, when the excitation wavelength is 400 nm (Figure a). We have also recorded the luminescence spectrum of the binuclear precursor of [Zn(salaepy)(ONO2)2]2 (Figure b). This compound also shows strong luminescence (λem = 430 nm, λex = 430 nm), which is assignable to intraligand 1(π*-π) fluorescence.

elements.content: (a) Luminescence spectrum of 5 in the solid state. (b) Luminescence spectrum of the binuclear complex [Zn(salaepy)(ONO2)2]2.
elements.clean_text: 9  (a) Luminescence spectrum of 5 in the solid state. (b) Luminescence spectrum of the binuclear complex [Zn(salaepy)(ONO2)2]2.

elements.content: In this article, we have illustrated that copper(II) and zinc(II) complexes with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands are useful tectons in constructing heterometallic complexes with interesting structural features. The Schiff base acts as a blocking ligand, leaving the other coordination sites of the metal(II) ion available for the interaction with bridging ligands. We have chosen as linkers for this work linear dicyanido–metallates or the simple cyanide anion. Two interesting synthetic aspects should be noticed: (i) the slow decomposition of the dicyanido–metallate complex, releasing cyanide ions, which, together with the parent [M(CN)2]− complexes, are also involved in the self-assembly processes; (ii) the double role played by the cyanide ion reacting with copper(II) complexes: reducing agent (part of the CuII ions are reduced to CuI) and bridging ligand. Such complexes are also of interest in molecular magnetism. Compound 1 allows the estimation of the exchange interaction transmitted through hydrogen bonds within a dimeric entity. Compound 2 is a rare example of a polynuclear complex where two copper(II) ions are connected by a cyanido ligand through their basal positions. The value of the corresponding exchange parameter was determined. The structures of the two CuII–AgI and CuII–CuI polymers, 3 and 4, are based on the zigzag chain motif, [M(CN)2] n n– observed in K[Cu(CN)2]. The zinc complexes with (NNO) ligands are good candidates for obtaining multimetallic systems showing luminescence that is different from one of the parent homometallic complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this article, we have illustrated that copper(II) and zinc(II) complexes with (NNO) Schiff-base ligands are useful tectons in constructing heterometallic complexes with interesting structural features. The Schiff base acts as a blocking ligand, leaving the other coordination sites of the metal(II) ion available for the interaction with bridging ligands. We have chosen as linkers for this work linear dicyanido-metallates or the simple cyanide anion. Two interesting synthetic aspects should be noticed: (i) the slow decomposition of the dicyanido-metallate complex, releasing cyanide ions, which, together with the parent [M(CN)2]- complexes, are also involved in the self-assembly processes; (ii) the double role played by the cyanide ion reacting with copper(II) complexes: reducing agent (part of the CuII ions are reduced to CuI) and bridging ligand. Such complexes are also of interest in molecular magnetism. Compound 1 allows the estimation of the exchange interaction transmitted through hydrogen bonds within a dimeric entity. Compound 2 is a rare example of a polynuclear complex where two copper(II) ions are connected by a cyanido ligand through their basal positions. The value of the corresponding exchange parameter was determined. The structures of the two CuII-AgI and CuII-CuI polymers, 3 and 4, are based on the zigzag chain motif, [M(CN)2] n   n- observed in K[Cu(CN)2]. The zinc complexes with (NNO) ligands are good candidates for obtaining multimetallic systems showing luminescence that is different from one of the parent homometallic complexes.

Green-blue crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by slow evaporation at room temperature. Yield: 85%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm–1): 3444(m), 2930(w), 2171(m), 2139(m), 1634(vs), 1598(vs), 1530(s), 1547(s), 1464(s), 1373(m), 1244(m), 1195(m), 906(w), 767(m), 542(w). Diffuse reflectance spectrum: 409 nm, and a large band between 600 and 800 nm.

cln_elements.content:
Dark brown crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction of this compound were prepared as for 3, but using KCN instead of K[Ag(CN)2]. Yield: 44%. Elemental chemical analysis: 47.58% C, 3.24% H, 13.85% N (calcd); 47.56% C, 2.95% H, 13.64% N (found). Selected IR data (KBr, cm–1): 2926(m), 2135(m), 2119(m), 16219(vs), 1535(m), 1487(s), 1448(m), 1347(m), 1200(m), 905(w), 767(s), 603(w), 520(w). Diffuse reflectance spectrum: 268 nm, 386 nm, and a large band between 400 and 700 nm.

Luminescence Properties

Zinc complexes with Schiff-base ligands are known to exhibit interesting luminescence properties, with emission bands currently located between 390 and 590 nm. The coordination of the ligands to the zinc ion increases the rigidity of the molecular edifice and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless thermal vibrations. The photoluminescent behavior of compound 5 was investigated in the solid state at room temperature. It exhibits strong blue luminescence with a peak maximum centered on λem = 464 nm, when the excitation wavelength is 400 nm (Figure a). We have also recorded the luminescence spectrum of the binuclear precursor of [Zn(salaepy)(ONO2)2]2 (Figure b). This compound also shows strong luminescence (λem = 430 nm, λex = 430 nm), which is assignable to intraligand 1(π*−π) fluorescence.
